questions.question: This UNESCO World Heritage Site in Southeast Asia is famous for its massive temples and was once the capital of the Khmer Empire. Known for its majestic Angkor Wat, it attracts millions of visitors annually.
questions.context: Angkor was the center of the Khmer Empire from the 9th to the 15th century and is a symbol of Cambodia today.

questions.question: This modern architectural marvel in North America, opened in 1976, is known for revolutionizing skyscraper designs with its tubular structure. It was once the tallest building in the world.

answer.label: Willis Tower (formerly Sears Tower), Chicago, USA

questions.context: Designed by architect Bruce Graham, the Willis Tower remains an icon of Chicago's skyline.

questions.question: In Northern Europe, this site marks where Napoleon decisively defeated the Russian and Austrian forces in 1805, solidifying his control over much of Europe.

answer.label: Austerlitz, Slavkov u Brna, Czech Republic

questions.context: The Battle of Austerlitz, also known as the Battle of the Three Emperors, was one of Napoleon's greatest victories.

questions.question: Located in Europe, this dark tourism site was a concentration camp during WWII and is now preserved to honor the memory of those who perished.
questions.context: Auschwitz-Birkenau is a symbol of the Holocaust and a stark reminder of the atrocities committed during this period.

questions.question: This famous museum in the Middle East is home to an extensive collection of Egyptian antiquities, including the treasures of Tutankhamun.
questions.context: Established in 1902, the museum showcases some of the world's most important artifacts from ancient Egypt.
